newsitem.title: GREECE: Greek Progress Fund H1 profit up 92.2 pct.
newsitem.headline: Greek Progress Fund H1 profit up 92.2 pct.

text.p: Closed-end fund Greek Progress said its half-year net profit rose 92.2 percent year-on-year to 2,276 million drachmas, mostly due to a jump in gains from portfolio transactions to 1.8 billion drachmas from year-earlier 0.74 billion.
The fund's portfolio had unrealised gains of 3.7 billion drachmas at end-June, climbing to 4.67 billion by July 14, 1997, it said in a statement.
On June 30, 1997 the fund's shares traded at a 25.6 percent discount to their net asset value (NAV) of 3,348 drachmas.
By July 14 NAV per share had risen to 3,505 and the dicount narrowed to 25 percent.
The fund said it had introduced more active asset management but would not deviate from its conservative investment approach and transaction costs would not be affected considerably.

It reshuffled its portfolio towards Athens bourse listings and away from foreign bonds, providing greater exposure to Greek securities for its foreign shareholders who hold 40 percent of its stock, it said.
Positions in ETBA Leasing, Benrubi, Volos Technical, Hellenic Fabrics, Katselis were shaken out in favour of additional positions in Mtka and Heracles Cement.
Its main equity positions included ErgoBank, Alpha Credit, Chipita, Goody's, Titan Cement, Hellenic Bottling, Delta Dairy and Papastratos, it said.
As of June 30, the fund was 81.3 percent invested in Athens-listed equities with non-listed stocks accounting for another 4.7 percent of its assets.
It reported the following asset allocation in its equity portfolio:
Food & Beverage 29.0%
Banks 20.5%
Building Materials 13.0%
Construction 11.4%
Telecoms 7.4%
Metallurgical 4.5%
Leasing 2.3%
Chemicals 2.2%
Tobacco 2.1%
Miscellaneous 7.6%
Progress Fund's shares lost 20 drachmas to 2,630 on Wednesday on volume of 28,700 shares.
--Angelos Kiosklis, Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4
